heisig_chinese_memo: My car is so fast it can go through ten rice fields in ten minutes.
heisig_story: You may keep the whole range of connotations for this keyword, car, provided it does not interfere with the pictograph. Look for the front and back wheels (the first and last horizontal strokes) and the seat in the carriage in the middle. As an exercise, try to isolate the primitives on your own and make a story out of them.

humanum_full_description_en:
A gold inscription is like the shape of a " car ", but the shape of the characters is changeable, and the writing method is very unstable. From time to time, all the wheels, shafts, shafts, yokes, shafts, and scales of the car are drawn. The original meaning is a vehicle. Bronze usually " car " put up writing, the scribe changed shape despite simplified, but still inherited the inscriptions erected writing habits. "Shuowen": "The name of the car, the name of the wheel. It was made by Xizhong in the post-summer time. Pictogram. All cars belong to the car. ğ¨–, the car." According to the " ğ¨– " in the " Suowen " text The wrong writing of the inscriptions of the Western Zhou Dynasty can be found in the ğ£ª• character form (Sun Yirang, Wang Guowei).

Oracle uses its original meaning to refer to vehicles. "He Ji" 11452: "Six cars." The word "carriage and horse" is often seen in the inscriptions. "He Ji" 11450: "car and horse." It is also used as a place name. "Just (in) the car."

Bronze inscriptions use its original meaning to refer to vehicles, and Fansheng has the term "Che Dian Zhen", which refers to the wooden stilts around the bottom of the ancient car. It is also extended to a military vehicle, not ğ¡¢ğ£ª•: "Female (Ru) Hugh, I am in a difficult situation." The whole sentence means that you should do it for yourself, and don't let my military vehicle get into trouble. It is also used as the clan name, and the fatherâ€™s own car trip: "Che." Also used as the person's name, the car trip: "Chezha (as) Baoding."

In addition, the inscription "æ—…" sometimes uses "è½¦" as the sound symbol, and sometimes directly uses "è½¦" as the provincial language of "æ—…". Cha Cha ğ£ª•: "Cha (ä½œ) Zun Che (æ—…) Bao Yi ."

The bamboo slips of the Warring States period use their original meaning to refer to vehicles, "Shangbo Bamboo Book One. "Yi Yi": "Sentence (gou) and (have) a car, you must see (see) not (its) rut." The full sentence means that if there is a car, the traces of its wheels must be visible. There is also the term "Che Shi", which refers to the punishment of car cracking, "Tsinghua Jane II. "Lian Year" Jane 12: "Che Shi Gao Zhi (qu) Er (Mi), change to Li Gong", that is, to punish Gao Qu Mi with car cracking, and change to support Li Gong.

Traditional characters for "è½¦1".
(1) Cars, vehicles on land with wheels.
(2) Especially refers to military vehicles.
(3) Refers to the impeller that propels the hull forward.
(4) Chariots, people who drive cars.
(5) Generally refers to tools that rotate on wheels.
(6) Machining and cutting objects. Today mostly refers to cutting things with a lathe.
(7) Refers to sewing with a machine.
(8) The water tanker holds water.
(9) Shipment by car.
(10) Rotating; turning sideways.
(11) Gum.
(12) Quantifiers. Calculate the unit of capacity contained in a vehicle.
(13) Last name. Han has a car forever.
